message_1: A sample of radioactive substance with an initial mass of 100 grams has a half-life of 10 days. How much of the substance will remain after 30 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 100 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 30 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^(30/10)

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^3

Final mass = 100 * (1/8)

Final mass = 12.5 grams

So, after 30 days, 12.5 grams of the radioactive substance will remain.
